content: The Act is titled the "Indian Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Improvement Act" and includes amendments to the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribes in law enforcement functions and expand the definition of entities covered by the Act. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribes in law enforcement functions and expand the definition of Indian tribe to include Alaska Native villages and corporations. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribes in law enforcement functions and expand the definition of Indian tribe to include Alaska Native villages and corporations. Federal Assistance for State and Local Programs and Programs for Indian Tribes is provided under Subpart I. The Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribes in law enforcement functions. Indian tribes' participation in cooperative programs will be funded separately. The amendment to the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 allows Indian tribes to participate in law enforcement functions through cooperative programs funded separately. The amendment specifies the assignment of responsibilities for the preparation and administration of the Indian tribe's part of the State plan. The amendment includes provisions for improving communication, cooperation, and intergovernmental relationships between the State, local governments, and Indian tribes in carrying out the plan under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974. It also requires a description and analysis of any disproportionate representation in the juvenile justice system. The amendment aims to address disproportionate representation of Native Americans in the juvenile justice system, including Alaska Natives from urban and non-recognized populations. Federal assistance for programs for Indian tribes is also included in the amendment. "Establishment of program for Federal Assistance for Programs for Indian Tribes." The Administrator will establish a program to provide direct grants to Indian tribes for projects related to compliance with juvenile justice system requirements and improvement activities. Indian tribes must submit a plan as part of their grant application. The Indian tribe must provide evidence of performing law enforcement functions, identify juvenile justice issues, establish fiscal control procedures, and meet additional requirements to receive grants for juvenile delinquency prevention activities. The Administrator may prescribe additional requirements to ensure grant program effectiveness. Factors considered for grant awards include available resources, coordination with the juvenile justice system, and population served by the grant. Grant awards are competitive, with annual awards given by the Administrator. The Administrator awards grants annually on a competitive basis, with grant agreements specifying terms. Grants are typically for 1 year, but exceptions may allow for renewal without competition if performance is satisfactory. The Administrator may renew grants for additional periods and make modifications to the application process for renewal grants. "Indian tribes receiving grants must comply with fiscal accountability provisions. The Administrator will provide technical assistance to help tribes with grant activities. Coordination with State Advisory Groups is required." "Under this subpart, the Administrator must issue reports to State advisory groups regarding grants awarded. The jurisdiction of Indian tribes in Alaska is not affected. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2001 for Department of Justice activities."
